data.title: NUSCALE POWER Corp SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
NuScale Power Corp, a leader in the development of Small Modular Reactor (SMR) technology, has released its annual 10-K report, providing a comprehensive overview of its financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces. The report underscores NuScale's commitment to redefining nuclear power through its innovative NuScale Power Module™ (NPM) technology, which emphasizes safety, scalability, and cost-effectiveness.

Financial Highlights

  • Revenue: $31.5 million. The decrease in revenue was primarily due to a reduction in revenue recognized from the RoPower technology license agreement executed in 2024.
  • Gross Margin: $11.4 million. The increase in cost of sales compared to the prior year was due to the engineering services required by Fluor under their FEED Phase 2 contract with RoPower.
  • Loss from Operations: $(689.6) million. The increase in loss from operations was primarily due to the recognition of Milestone Contribution 1 of $507.4 million and higher strategic business development costs.
  • Net Loss: $(664.5) million. The net loss increased due to the trigger of Milestone Contribution 1 under the PMA and additional payments toward the acquisition and construction of long-lead material.
  • Net Cash Used in Operating Activities: $(459.6) million. Cash used in operations increased due to the trigger of Milestone Contribution 1 and payments associated with the tri-Party Agreement with the U.S. Department of Energy.

Business Highlights

  • Business Overview: NuScale is redefining nuclear power with its proprietary Small Modular Reactor (SMR) technology, the NuScale Power Module™ (NPM), which generates 77 MWe. The technology focuses on safety, scalability, and cost-effectiveness, leveraging passive safety features and a simplified design.
  • Regulatory Milestones: In May 2025, NuScale received approval from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) for its 6-unit 77 MWe NPM design, allowing U.S. customers to expedite construction and operating licensing.
  • International Market Development: NuScale has partnered with RoPower Nuclear S.A. in Romania to deploy a 6-unit 77 MWe NPM design at the Doicesti Power Station. The Romanian government approved the investment decision in February 2026, advancing the project to the next phase.
  • Strategic Partnerships: NuScale has contracted with ENTRA1 as its global strategic partner for the commercialization and development of power plants utilizing NPMs. ENTRA1 holds exclusive rights for worldwide commercialization, distribution, sales, and development of NuScale's products.
  • Geographical Performance: The demand for energy in foreign markets, particularly in Asia, is driven by population growth, industrialization, and urbanization. NuScale is focusing on these regions for long-term growth.
  • Domestic Market Focus: In the U.S., the demand for energy is driven by the growth of the data center industry and the government's objective to expand nuclear energy capacity to 400 gigawatts by 2050.
  • Technology and Safety Innovations: NuScale's NPM design incorporates proven light water reactor technology, natural circulation cooling, and a multi-module control room, enhancing safety and reducing operational costs.
  • Supply Chain and Manufacturing: NuScale has placed orders for long-lead items for the first twelve NPM upper reactor vessels and is progressing with manufacturing trials for key components, leveraging a global supply chain.
  • Future Outlook: NuScale aims to grow by replacing carbon-intensive coal-fired plants, expanding internationally, and developing new products like micro-reactors for niche markets. The company is also focused on advancing its technology platform and intellectual property portfolio.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Strategic Focus: NuScale is focused on commercializing its modular, scalable nuclear power technology, partnering with ENTRA1 for global commercialization and development. The company is advancing its strategic partnership with ENTRA1 to position its SMR technology in ENTRA1 Energy Plants, particularly targeting the Tennessee Valley Authority for up to 6 gigawatts of new nuclear power generation.
  • Capital Management: NuScale has been actively managing its capital through at-the-market (ATM) equity programs, raising significant funds to support its commercialization efforts. In 2025, the company issued and sold shares of Class A common stock for gross proceeds of $1,327.6 million through its Q4 2025 and Q3 2025 ATM Programs. The company has no debt and maintains a strong cash position with $836.4 million in cash and cash equivalents and $450.8 million in liquid investments as of December 31, 2025. NuScale has also entered into various purchase commitments to support the development of its NPMs.
  • Future Outlook: NuScale anticipates significant customer demand for its SMR technology outside the United States, driven by global trends in decarbonization and renewable energy demand. The company plans to continue its strategic partnership with ENTRA1 to expand its market presence and is focused on securing regulatory approvals to facilitate broader adoption of its technology. NuScale believes it has sufficient cash and access to capital markets to meet its cash requirements for the next 12 months and beyond, as it transitions from R&D to commercialization.

Challenges and Risks

  • Market and Operational Risks: NuScale faces unique challenges and risks as it redefines nuclear power with its SMR technology. The company has not yet entered into a binding contract to deliver its NPMs, which could delay deployment and impact financial performance. The market for SMRs is not yet established, and competition from other nuclear technologies and international players like China and Russia poses significant challenges. Additionally, the company relies heavily on strategic partnerships, which, if terminated, could hinder commercialization efforts.
  • Corporate Structure and Tax Risks: As a holding company, NuScale depends on distributions from NuScale LLC, and any financial deterioration of the subsidiary could impact liquidity. The company is also subject to complex tax arrangements, including a Tax Receivable Agreement that could result in substantial payments, potentially exceeding actual tax benefits.
  • Regulatory and Reputational Risks: Regulatory risks are significant, as the company must obtain approvals in each country it operates, and changes in U.S. trade policy could affect costs and supply chain dynamics. The public perception of nuclear energy and potential accidents pose reputational risks, while the constrained supply base could impact production schedules and costs.
  • Management's Discussion and Analysis: Management acknowledges the challenges of scaling production and securing contracts for NPMs. The company is focused on refining its design and manufacturing processes to enhance competitiveness. However, the need for additional funding to support operations and commercialization efforts is critical, and the company may face difficulties in securing financing on favorable terms. The potential loss of government incentives for nuclear power could also adversely affect market demand.
  • Market Risks: NuScale is exposed to market risks, including fluctuations in electricity prices and changes in regulatory environments. The company’s ability to compete in markets with low power prices is uncertain, and inflation could increase the cost of NPMs, affecting competitiveness. Additionally, cybersecurity risks are a concern, as breaches could impact operations and reputation. The company is also subject to risks from potential litigation, which could divert resources and impact financial performance.

SEC Filing: NUSCALE POWER Corp [ SMR ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: H2O AMERICA SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
H2O America, a leading water utility company, has released its annual Form 10-K report, detailing significant financial growth, strategic initiatives, and operational challenges. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's performance in 2025, highlighting key financial metrics, business operations, strategic plans, and the risks it faces in the evolving regulatory and market environment.

Financial Highlights

Operating Revenue: $800.59 million, reflecting a 7% increase from 2024 primarily due to rate increases in California and Connecticut.

Operating Income: $177.53 million, up from $170.50 million in 2024, driven by higher revenue despite increased administrative and general expenses.

Net Income: $102.58 million, representing a 9% increase from 2024, primarily driven by higher revenue associated with rate increases.

Diluted EPS: $2.92, compared to $2.87 in 2024, reflecting improved profitability and operational efficiency.

Business Highlights

Revenue Segments: Water Utility Services generated revenue from residential and business customers, industrial customers, public authorities, and other segments. The residential and business segment was the largest contributor, followed by public authorities and industrial customers.

Geographical Performance: H2O America operates in California, Connecticut, Texas, and Maine. Each region has distinct regulatory environments and operational challenges. California's operations are subject to CPUC regulations, Connecticut's to PURA, Texas's to PUCT, and Maine's to MPUC.

Sales Units: SJWC provides water services to approximately 232,000 connections, serving about one million people. CTWS serves approximately 143,000 connections, and TWC serves around 30,000 connections.

Future Outlook: H2O America plans to invest approximately $458 million in 2026 for capital improvements, excluding the Quadvest acquisition. The company also anticipates significant capital expenditures for PFAS treatment compliance by 2029.

Operational Challenges: The company faces challenges related to regulatory compliance, environmental standards, and water supply management, particularly in California due to long-term water supply issues.

Customer Growth: The company is focused on organic growth within its service areas and acquiring regulated water systems near its existing territories. The anticipated acquisition of Quadvest is expected to enhance operational scale and development pipeline.

Regulatory Environment: Each state has specific regulatory mechanisms, such as WICA in Connecticut and SIC in Texas, to address infrastructure investment and regulatory lag. These mechanisms help mitigate financial risks associated with regulatory changes.

Strategic Initiatives

Strategic Growth: H2O America is pursuing strategic growth through acquisitions, exemplified by the planned acquisition of Quadvest, L.P. and Quadvest Wholesale LLC, which is expected to enhance operational scale and development pipeline in the Houston, TX region. The company is also focusing on expanding its regulated customer base by acquiring water systems adjacent to existing territories.

Capital Management: In 2025, H2O America raised $185.2 million through long-term debt issuances and $122.8 million from equity offerings. The company also paid $58.6 million in dividends, representing 57% of net income, and has a history of increasing annual dividends for 58 consecutive years. The company maintains unsecured bank lines of credit totaling $370 million and has been actively managing its debt portfolio with new issuances and repayments to support capital expenditures and working capital needs.

Future Outlook: H2O America plans to invest approximately $458 million in capital expenditures in 2026, excluding acquisitions, with a focus on distribution system investments and compliance with environmental regulations. Over the next five years, the company expects to incur $2.568 billion in capital expenditures, including $400 million for PFAS treatment. The company aims to maintain access to external funding sources to support its capital investment programs and strategic growth initiatives.

Challenges and Risks

Operational and Integration Risks: H2O America, formerly SJW Group, is undergoing significant changes, including the acquisition of Quadvest, which introduces new operational and integration risks. The company is expanding its operations in Texas, which will increase its exposure to regulatory and market risks in that region.

Regulatory Risks: The proposed acquisition of Quadvest presents several risks, including regulatory approval delays, integration challenges, and potential failure to realize anticipated benefits. The company faces significant regulatory risks, particularly in obtaining necessary approvals from the Public Utility Commission of Texas (PUCT) and other regulatory bodies. Additionally, the integration of Quadvest's business may be complex and time-consuming, potentially impacting customer relationships and operational efficiency.

Litigation Risks: H2O America is also exposed to litigation risks, particularly concerning water quality and contamination. A class action lawsuit against a subsidiary, CWC, highlights the potential for significant legal costs and reputational damage. The company’s operations are subject to stringent environmental regulations, which could increase compliance costs and impact financial performance.

Water Supply Adequacy: The company faces operational risks related to water supply adequacy, which depends on factors such as rainfall, reservoir levels, and regulatory restrictions. Water shortages could lead to increased costs and operational challenges. The concentration of business in California, Texas, and Connecticut makes H2O America susceptible to regional risks, including political, regulatory, and environmental challenges.

Market Risks: H2O America is exposed to market risks, including interest rate fluctuations that could impact the cost of capital. The company’s substantial indebtedness, particularly related to the Quadvest acquisition, may reduce financial flexibility and increase borrowing costs. Additionally, the company faces risks related to inflation, which could increase operational costs and impact profitability if not offset by rate increases.

SEC Filing: H2O AMERICA [ HTO ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc., a specialty finance company focused on lending to middle-market companies, has released its 2025 10-K report. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in the current market environment.

Financial Highlights

Total Investment Income: $365.57 million, a decrease from $434.37 million in 2024, primarily due to a decline in base interest rates and tightening of credit spreads.

Net Investment Income After Taxes: $181.57 million, down from $252.55 million in 2024, reflecting lower total investment income.

Net Realized and Unrealized Gains (Losses): $(62.22) million, an improvement from $(189.50) million in 2024, driven by restructuring and exits of certain investments.

Net Increase (Decrease) in Net Assets from Operations: $119.27 million, up from $62.87 million in 2024, due to improved net realized and unrealized gains.

Basic and Diluted Net Investment Income Per Share: $1.57, a decrease from $2.20 in 2024, reflecting lower net investment income.

Business Highlights

Business Model: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. operates as a specialty finance company focused on lending to middle-market companies, primarily through direct originations of secured debt and select equity investments.

Investment Strategy: The company emphasizes leading the negotiation and structuring of loans or securities and holding investments to maturity, with a focus on investments that have maturities of three to ten years.

Portfolio Composition: As of December 31, 2025, the investment portfolio consisted of 564 investments in 171 portfolio companies across 40 industries, with a significant focus on software, healthcare providers & services, and healthcare technology.

Geographical Performance: The portfolio's geographic composition was primarily in the United States (94.8%), with additional investments in Canada (3.2%), the United Kingdom (1.5%), and India (0.5%).

Investment Yield: The weighted average yield on the total portfolio was 9.3% at amortized cost and 10.5% at fair value, indicating a strong return on investments.

Market Opportunity: The company identifies a large target market opportunity in the U.S. middle market, driven by a significant number of middle-market companies and a large amount of un-invested private equity capital.

Competitive Advantages: The company leverages Goldman Sachs' global platform, direct origination capabilities, and structuring expertise to source and manage investments effectively.

Future Outlook: The company plans to continue focusing on secured debt investments and may also invest in opportunistic investments to enhance risk-adjusted returns. It aims to provide consistent dividend distributions and attractive total returns to stockholders.

Strategic Initiatives

Strategic Debt Management: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. has focused on strategic debt management by repaying the 2025 Notes using proceeds from its Revolving Credit Facility and cash on hand. The company also issued $400 million of 2030 Notes and $400 million of 2029 Notes to align its debt maturity profile and interest rate exposure with its investment portfolio. Additionally, the company has entered into interest rate swaps to hedge against interest rate fluctuations, enhancing its financial stability.

Capital Management: The company has been actively managing its capital structure through a stock repurchase program, authorizing up to $75 million for repurchases if the stock trades below NAV. It also declared a quarterly base distribution and a supplemental distribution, reflecting its commitment to returning capital to shareholders. The company maintains a voluntary dividend reinvestment plan, allowing shareholders to reinvest dividends into additional shares. Furthermore, the company has utilized its Revolving Credit Facility to manage liquidity and support its investment activities.

Future Outlook: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. plans to continue leveraging its Revolving Credit Facility and explore additional credit facilities to capitalize on investment opportunities. The company aims to maintain a balanced approach to capital management, focusing on debt reduction and shareholder returns. It anticipates further strategic use of interest rate swaps to manage interest rate risk and align its liabilities with its predominantly floating rate investment portfolio.

Challenges and Risks

Market Risks: The company faces significant market risks due to potential disruptions and instability in capital markets, which could negatively impact debt and equity capital markets, affecting business operations. Political, social, and economic uncertainties, including conflicts and natural disasters, exacerbate these risks.

Regulatory Constraints: Regulatory constraints as a BDC limit operational flexibility and could lead to additional restrictions if BDC status is lost. The company must maintain RIC status to avoid corporate tax rates, which requires meeting specific distribution and diversification requirements.

Operational Risks: Cybersecurity incidents and reliance on information systems pose operational risks, potentially disrupting business and affecting financial conditions. The use of artificial intelligence introduces new risks, including data inaccuracies and increased competition, which could adversely impact operations.

Management Strategies: Management acknowledges the challenges posed by market volatility and economic conditions, which may limit investment opportunities and increase funding costs. The company plans to manage these risks by maintaining a diversified investment portfolio and leveraging its relationship with Goldman Sachs for strategic advantages. However, the competitive market for investment opportunities remains a significant challenge, with many competitors having greater resources and risk tolerance.

Interest Rate Risks: The company is exposed to interest rate fluctuations, which could impact the cost of debt and the ability to raise new capital. Inflation and changes in Federal Reserve policies may further affect borrowing costs and investment returns. The company employs interest rate swaps to mitigate some of these risks but acknowledges the inherent uncertainties in market conditions.

SEC Filing: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. [ GSBD ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: CME GROUP INC. SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
CME Group Inc., a leading global financial exchange, has released its 2025 Form 10-K report, showcasing robust financial performance, strategic growth initiatives, and a comprehensive overview of the challenges and risks faced by the company. The report highlights the company's efforts to expand its product offerings, enhance technological capabilities, and maintain a strong capital management strategy in a highly competitive and regulated environment.

Financial Highlights

  • Total Revenues: $6,520.6 million, reflecting a 6% increase from 2024, driven by higher clearing and transaction fees and market data services.
  • Operating Income: $4,229.5 million, showing an increase due to higher revenues and effective cost management.
  • Net Income: $4,072.2 million, a 15% increase from 2024, attributed to increased revenues and investment income.
  • Diluted EPS: $11.16, up 15% from 2024, reflecting strong financial performance and efficient capital management.

Business Highlights

  • Revenue Segments: CME Group's revenue is primarily derived from clearing and transaction fees, including electronic trading fees, surcharges for privately negotiated transactions, and other volume-related charges for exchange-traded and over-the-counter (OTC) contracts. The company also generates revenue from market data and information services, as well as other services related to exchange operations.
  • Geographical Performance: In 2025, approximately 31% of CME Group's electronic futures and options volume was from transactions reported as outside the U.S., and approximately 53% of market data revenue was derived from outside the U.S. The company achieved 6% growth in trading volume during European trading hours and 13% growth during Asia Pacific trading hours compared to 2024.
  • Sales Units: CME Group reported a total contract volume of 7,060.4 million in 2025, a 6% increase from 2024. The average daily volume for interest rate products was 14,203 contracts, equity indexes 7,410 contracts, foreign exchange 980 contracts, energy 2,695 contracts, agricultural commodities 1,853 contracts, and metals 988 contracts.
  • New Product Launches: In 2025, CME Group launched several new products, including micro-sized contracts across all six major derivatives asset classes, and expanded into Credit, Treasury bills, and TBA Mortgage futures. The company also introduced CME FX Spot+ and BrokerTec Chicago to enhance its product offerings.
  • Future Outlook: CME Group plans to offer 24/7 trading for its entire crypto suite in Q2 2026, enabling customers to hedge exposure to underlying cash markets throughout the weekend. The company is also focused on expanding its presence in the Middle East with the opening of a Dubai office and continues to target cross-asset opportunities across client segments and platforms.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Strategic Initiatives: CME Group's strategic initiatives focus on maximizing futures and options growth globally, diversifying business and revenues, and enhancing customer efficiencies through partnerships, such as with Google Cloud. The company aims to develop into a more diversified financial exchange offering trading and clearing solutions across various products and asset classes.
  • Capital Management: CME Group has a robust capital management strategy that includes maintaining a $2.3 billion multi-currency revolving senior credit facility and a $7.0 billion 364-day multi-currency revolving secured credit facility. The company also has a share repurchase program authorized up to $3.0 billion and declared regular quarterly dividends, with a target payout of 50% to 60% of the prior year's cash earnings. In 2025, the company repurchased $266.1 million of its Class A common stock and declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.30 per share, along with an additional annual variable dividend of $6.15 per share.
  • Future Outlook: CME Group plans to continue its strategic focus on global growth in futures and options, leveraging technology partnerships to enhance operational excellence. The company anticipates future capital expenditures of approximately $85.0 million in 2026 to support growth through increased system capacity and performance improvements. Additionally, CME Group intends to maintain its investment-grade credit rating and continue its dividend policy, subject to board discretion and financial conditions.

Challenges and Risks

  • Market Risks: The company's revenue is heavily dependent on trading volumes, which are influenced by global economic and political conditions, competition, and market volatility. A reduction in trading volume could adversely affect financial results.
  • Operational Risks: The company relies on technology and third-party service providers, making it vulnerable to cyber attacks, system failures, and capacity constraints. Any significant disruption could impact operations and financial performance.
  • Regulatory Risks: Operating in a heavily regulated industry, CME Group faces significant compliance costs and potential changes in legislation that could impact its business model. New regulations on digital assets and event-based contracts could introduce additional scrutiny and litigation risks.
  • Emerging Risks: The use of artificial intelligence presents new challenges, including potential biases, intellectual property issues, and regulatory compliance. The company must also address risks related to climate change and social concerns, which could affect its reputation and operations.

SEC Filing: CME GROUP INC. [ CME ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: J.M. Smucker Adds Directors in Deal With Activist Firm Elliott — WSJ
data.description:
By Jesse Newman and Nicholas G. Miller

J.M. Smucker struck an agreement with activist investor Elliott Investment Management and appointed two new members to its board as the jam-and-jelly maker struggles with core parts of its business.

Following "constructive engagement" with Elliott, Smucker said Woo-Sung "Bruce" Chung and David Singer would join its board, effective April 15. Chief Executive Mark Smucker said that the company has met several times with Elliott and that the focus is on boosting Smucker's sales, restoring profit and disciplined capital allocation.

"The engagement with Elliott is recent and has actually been very constructive," said Smucker, speaking on the company's quarterly investor call.

Marc Steinberg, partner at Elliott, said that as one of Smucker's largest investors, the firm believes the new directors and other measures represent critical steps toward ensuring the Ohio-based company reaches its full potential.

Smucker shares closed about 9% higher Thursday.

Smucker on Thursday posted higher third-quarter sales, buoyed by price increases in its coffee division, but the company lowered its sales-growth forecast for the year because of a recent fire at one of its manufacturing facilities.

The company reported a loss of $724.2 million, compared with a loss of $662.3 million the year prior. Adjusted earnings were $2.38 a share, above the $2.27 anticipated among analysts polled by FactSet.

Net sales rose 7% to $2.34 billion, outpacing analysts' expectations. The sales growth included a 10-percentage-point increase from net price realization, primarily due to higher prices for coffee.

Coffee prices surged last year after adverse weather in top coffee-producing countries hurt supply and President Trump's tariffs increased the cost to import coffee beans. The company raised prices last year in response to those increased costs. It was planning an additional price increase this winter, but held off after the U.S. excluded raw coffee from tariffs.

Sales have struggled for Smucker's Hostess business, acquired in 2023 through a $5 billion deal that added brands like Twinkies and Donettes.

Smucker said Thursday comparable sales in its sweet-baked-goods unit, which includes Hostess, declined 11% for the latest quarter. Profit fell 78% and the company said it took two impairment charges tied to Hostess totaling nearly $1 billion.

"The path to stabilization is taking longer than we expected," said Smucker, the CEO.

Smucker said it has been working to reduce the number of Hostess products by 25%, to focus more on Cupcakes, Twinkies and Donettes. Closing an Indianapolis plant is expected to save $30 million annually, the CEO said, and promotions are being reduced until the end of the company's fiscal year.

Smucker Chief Financial Officer Tucker Marshall said it is hard to predict where Hostess's sales will go in the next fiscal year. "But we should begin to build back profitability because we're at such a low watermark," he said.

The company narrowed its forecast for fiscal-year net sales growth to 3.5% to 4%, compared with its previous forecast of 3.5% to 4.5%. It reiterated its adjusted earnings guidance of $8.75 to $9.25 a share. Analysts see adjusted earnings of $8.99 a share.

The change in the net-sales guidance was because of a recent fire at the company's Emporia, Kan., manufacturing facility.

Write to Jesse Newman at jesse.newman@wsj.com and Nicholas G. Miller at nicholas.miller@wsj.com

data.title: NHC Reports 2025 Year End Earnings
data.description:
(22:30 GMT) *National Healthcare 4Q EPS $1.58 >NHC
(22:30 GMT) Press Release: NHC Reports 2025 Year End Earnings

MURFREESBORO, Tenn.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 26, 2026--

National HealthCare Corporation (NYSE American: NHC), the nation's oldest publicly traded senior health care company, announced today net operating revenues and grant income for the year ended December 31, 2025 totaled $1,517,781,000 compared to $1,307,382,000 for the year ended December 31, 2024, an increase of 16.1%. The increase in net operating revenues for the 2025 year compared to the 2024 year was due to an 8.4% increase in same-facility net operating revenues, as well as the August 1, 2024 acquisition of White Oak Manor ("White Oak"). The White Oak operations consist of 22 healthcare operations, which includes 15 skilled nursing facilities, two assisted living facilities, four independent living facilities, and a long-term care pharmacy.

For the year ended December 31, 2025, the reported GAAP net income attributable to NHC was $120,015,000 compared to $101,927,000 for the 2024 year. Excluding the unrealized gains in our marketable equity securities portfolio and other non-GAAP adjustments, adjusted net income for the year ended December 31, 2025 was $104,067,000 compared to $76,862,000 for the 2024 year (*) , an increase of 35.4%. GAAP diluted earnings per share were $7.67 and $6.53 for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively. Adjusted diluted earnings per share were $6.65 and $4.93 for the years ended December 31, 2025 and 2024, respectively (*) .

For the quarter ended December 31, 2025, the reported GAAP net income attributable to NHC was $24,849,000 compared to $6,081,000 for the same period in 2024. Excluding the unrealized gains or losses in our marketable equity securities portfolio and other non-GAAP adjustments, adjusted net income for the quarter ended December 31, 2025 was $28,774,000 compared to $25,954,000 for the same period in 2024, an increase of 10.9% (*) . The GAAP diluted earnings per share were $1.58 and $0.39 for the quarters ended December 31, 2025 and 2024, respectively. Adjusted diluted earnings per share were $1.83 and $1.66 for the quarters ended December 31, 2025 and 2024, respectively (*) .

(*) - See the tables below that provide a reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP items.

About NHC

As of February 1, 2026, NHC affiliates operate for themselves and third parties 80 skilled nursing facilities with 10,329 beds. NHC affiliates also operate 26 assisted living communities with 1,413 units, nine independent living communities with 777 units, three behavioral health hospitals, 34 homecare agencies, and 33 hospice agencies. NHC's other services include Alzheimer's and memory care units, pharmacy services, a rehabilitation services company, and providing management and accounting services to third party post-acute operators. Other information about the company can be found on our web site at www.nhccare.com.

Non-GAAP Financial Presentation

The Company is providing certain non-GAAP financial measures as the Company believes that these figures are helpful in allowing investors to more accurately assess the ongoing nature of the Company's operations and measure the Company's performance more consistently across periods. Therefore, the Company believes this information is meaningful in addition to the information contained in the GAAP presentation of financial information. The presentation of this additional non-GAAP financial information is not intended to be considered in isolation or as a substitute for the financial information prepared and presented in accordance with GAAP.

Forward-Looking Statements

Statements in this press release that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. NHC cautions investors that any forward-looking statements made involve risks and uncertainties and are not guarantees of future performance. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in reports filed by NHC with the S.E.C., including Forms 8-K, 10-Q, and 10-K. All forward-looking statements represent NHC's best judgment as of the date of this release.

data.title: EV Nickel Announces Maiden Mineral Resource Estimate for Gemini North Nickel Zone
data.description:
NOT FOR DISSEMINATION IN THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA OR TO US WIRE SERVICES

  • Distinct deposit to CarLang A with significant "Mt. Keith Style" primary sulphide mineralization with higher confirmed nickel recoveries

  • Gemini North Zone Resources total 93.5M tonnes, averaging 0.23% Ni (US$7.35/t NSR cut-off), split between:

    • Indicated Resources of 9.5M tonnes at 0.27% containing 56Mlbs of nickel, and

    • Inferred Resources of 84.0M tonnes at 0.22% Ni containing 411Mlbs of nickel

  • The Gemini North Zone contains a potential Pit Constrained Starter Zone of 25.5M tonnes grading 0.27% Ni and 0.34% S consisting of both Indicated and Inferred Resources

TORONTO, ON / ACCESS Newswire / February 26, 2026 / EV NICKEL INC. ("EVNi" or the "Company") today announced a maiden mineral resource estimate for the "Gemini North Zone", part of its large-scale nickel target in the northeast of its Shaw Dome Project, referred to as the Carman-Langmuir or, "CarLang Area" (the "Property" or the "Project") (Figure 1). A Technical Report in support of the Mineral Resource Estimate will be filed on SEDAR+ (www.sedarplus.ca) within 45 days. The Mineral Resource Estimate is effective as of February 26, 2026.

After discovery of the Gemini North Nickel Zone (see News Release dated October 8, 2024), EVNi launched a diamond drilling program (23 holes totalling 6,682 m) to complete a maiden mineral resource estimate in accordance with National Instrument 43-101 ("NI 43-101") which shows Indicated Resources of 9.5M tonnes or 55.6M pounds of contained nickel and Inferred Resources of 84.0M tonnes or 410.7M pounds of contained nickel (Table 1 and Figure 2).

"The Gemini North Preliminary Resources Estimate demonstrates the great potential of the CarLang Trend," said Paul Davis, Vice President Exploration. "The identification of Mt. Keith Style, nickel-copper-PGM sulphide mineralization at Gemini North with better metallurgical recovery characteristics, only represents a small portion of the overall CarLang C area. When combined with the potential to identify multiple, proximal, large-scale deposits along the CarLang Trend (A, B, C, E and Gemini North), would allow for a single, centralized processing plant to process all the potential zones within the interpreted 10km strike length of peridotites and dunites."

Table 1 - Preliminary Mineral Resource Estimate for the Shaw Dome Project's Gemini North Nickel Zone.

Notes to Table 1:

1. The independent Qualified Person for the Mineral Resource Estimate, as defined by National Instrument 43-101 - Standards of Disclosure for Mineral Projects ("NI 43-101"), is Dr. Scott Jobin-Bevans (P.Geo., PGO #0183) of Caracle Creek International Consulting Inc. The effective date of the Mineral Resource Estimate is February 26, 2025.

2. The quantity and grade of reported Inferred Mineral Resources in this MRE are uncertain in nature and there has been insufficient exploration to define these Inferred Mineral Resources as Indicated or Measured Mineral Resources. However, it is reasonably expected that the majority of Inferred Mineral Resources could be upgraded to Indicated Mineral Resources with continued exploration.

3. Estimation domains were built from geological data with the exception of high-grade domains which were constrained using grade thresholds based on statistical analysis of the core assays.

4. The Mineral Resource is reported at an NSR break-even cut-off of US$7.35/t based on commodity prices, metallurgical recoveries, selling costs, operating costs, and appropriate mine modifying factors.

5. Geological and block models for the MRE used data from a total of 23 surface drill holes, completed by EV Nickel in 2025. The drill hole database was validated prior to resource estimation and QA/QC checks were made using industry-standard control charts for blanks, core duplicates and commercial certified reference material inserted into assay batches by EV Nickel and by comparison of umpire assays performed at a second laboratory.

6. Estimates have been rounded to two significant figures.

7. The MRE was prepared following the CIM Estimation of Mineral Resources & Mineral Reserves Best Practice Guidelines (November 29, 2019) and the CIM Definition Standards for Mineral Resources & Mineral Reserves (May 19, 2014).

8. A 10 m x 10 m x 10 m block model was created, and samples were composited at 1.5 m intervals. Grade estimation from drill hole data was carried out for Ni, Co, Pd, Pt, Fe and S using the Ordinary Kriging interpolation method in Micromine software.

9. The MRE has been constrained by a conceptual pit envelope that was developed using the following optimization parameters:

  • Mining costs and revenues reported in US dollars (US$)

  • Metal prices used were US$21,000/t nickel, US$40,000/t cobalt, US$325/t iron, US$3,860/t chromium, US$1,350/oz palladium, and US$1,150/oz platinum.

  • Pit slope angle of 45 degrees was applied

  • Processing costs and general and administration costs of US$7.35/t for 100 ktpd operation

  • Recovery percentage for the metals are: Ni% is 171.63 × S% + 21.2; Co is 11%; Pt is 22%; Pd is 48%; and Fe is 53%.

10. The Mineral Resource statement reports pit-constrained resources using both NiEq and NSR calculated within an optimised open pit. Block value was calculated as:

  • NSR ($/t) = NSR_Ni + NSR_Co + NSR_Pt + NSR_Pd + NSR_Fe

  • NiEq (%) = Ni% + (Ni%×NSR_Co/NSR_Ni) + (Ni%×NSR_Pt/NSR_Ni) + (Ni%×NSR_Pd/NSR_Ni) + (Ni%×NSR_Fe/NSR_Ni)

The NSR values for each metal was determined using the metal prices and recoveries stated in point 9.

11. Grade estimation was validated by comparison of input and output statistics (Nearest Neighbour and Inverse Distance Squared methods), swath plot analysis, cross-plots of declustered samples against the nearest Ordinary Kriging estimate, and by visual inspection of the assay data, block model, and grade shells in cross-sections.

12. Density estimation is based on referential density information benchmarked from similar deposits and projects. Lithology-specific values were applied: the average estimated density for peridotite, komatiite, and pyroxenite is 2.76 g/cm³ (t/m³).

Figure 2: Isometric View Showing the pit shell (light grey) with respect to the modelled Indicated and Inferred Resources

Potential for the Gemini North Nickel Zone- Open along strike and at depth

The potential exists at Gemini North to sequence the potential extraction of the zone focusing on the higher-grade nickel and sulphur portions of the deposit. Table 2 summarizes the pit constrained Indicated and Inferred Resources and highlights the potential to sequence the open pit to extract higher nickel and sulphur grade material that appear to have better metallurgical recovery characteristics associated with nickel in sulphides as reported in a press release issued January 27, 2026. The Company will continue to explore the potential of the Gemini North, to define a starter open pit to maximize the economic value of the deposit and the potential to improved economic expectations for the area.

Additionally, the Gemini North Nickel Zone is still open along strike to the east, west and at depth as indicated by drill holes not included in the current resource, surface sampling and the extension of the modeled mineralization below the current pit constrained resource.

When taken into consideration that the Gemini North Nickel Deposit covers less than 10% of the overall CarLang C target area, the potential to expand the resources in this area is significant.

Drilling Data Detail

EV Nickel's Gemini North drill program targeted the Large-Scale potential of the Gemini North Nickel Zone, forming only the northern portion of the CarLang C target area, and was completed in 2024 and 2025. The maiden mineral resource estimate consists of 23 holes totalling 6,682 m (see Tables 3 & 4 and Figure 3). The Gemini North Nickel Zone is defined across a strike length of 990 metres, a width of 580 metres and a depth of 360 metres. Nickel mineralization extends below 300 metres vertical depth with a number of drill holes bottoming in nickel mineralization.

Core Handling and Assay-QA/QC Procedures

NQ-sized drill core from the Phase 2 Diamond Drill Hole Program, part of the Shaw Dome Project, was sawn in half at the Company's core logging facility located near the Project site. One half of the core was retained for reference, and the remaining half was bagged and transported to Activation Laboratories Limited ("Actlabs") in Timmins, Ontario, for sample preparation and analysis.

Certified reference materials and blanks were inserted into the sample stream by the Company as part of its quality assurance and quality control ("QA/QC") program; no QA/QC issues were noted by the Company or its consultants. At Actlabs, samples were crushed to 80% passing 2 mm, with a riffle split pulverized to 95% passing 105 microns. Nickel, copper, cobalt, iron, and sulphur were analyzed by Sodium Peroxide Fusion with an ICP-OES finish. Gold, platinum, and palladium were analyzed by Fire Assay with an ICP-OES finish.

Assay results may vary from time to time due to re-analysis conducted as part of ongoing QA/QC procedures.

About EV Nickel Inc.

EV Nickel's mission is to provide the world with clean nickel from Tier 1 jurisdictions. Our projects are located within 30 km of Timmins, a developing hub of clean critical minerals for the North American battery and stainless-steel markets, as well as an important emerging critical mineral district for North American efforts to bring on-shore the full vertical integration of electric batteries and vehicles.

EV Nickel aims to play an integral part of the North American on-shoring initiative as the Company's clean, low carbon deposits can be an important source of supply to support the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) and Ontario and Federal policies and initiatives which strive to bring clean critical mineral production from Canada into the North American supply chain and globally.

In further support of this initiative, the Company has and will continue to partner with environmentally responsible and ethical organizations from around the province and around the world to assist in developing these essential critical minerals. EV Nickel is also eager to collaborate with all stakeholders and leading sustainable engineering, mining, automotive and battery companies to provide this key input to support global decarbonization initiatives. The governments of Ontario and Canada are also providing significant legislative, policy and financial support to help ensure that the Timmins region becomes a leading participant in the developing North American supply chain for the clean energy transition.

Qualified Person

The independent Qualified Person for the Mineral Resource Estimate, as defined by National Instrument 43-101 - Standards of Disclosure for Mineral Projects ("NI 43-101"), is Dr. Scott Jobin-Bevans (P.Geo., PGO #0183) of Caracle Creek International Consulting Inc.

The Company's Projects are under the direct technical supervision of Paul Davis, P.Geo., and Vice-President of the Company. Mr. Davis is a Qualified Person as defined by NI 43-101. He has reviewed and approved the technical information in this press release. There are no known factors that could materially affect the reliability of the information verified by Mr. Davis.

data.title: Andean Precious Metals Reports Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2025 Production Results and Provides 2026 Production and Cost Guidance
data.description:
Highest Production Quarter of 2025, Supported by Record Realized Prices

(All amounts in U.S. dollars unless otherwise indicated)

Toronto, Ontario--(Newsfile Corp. - February 26, 2026) - Andean Precious Metals Corp.  (OTCQX: ANPMF) ("Andean" or the "Company") is pleased to report its operational results for the quarter and year ended December 31, 2025, along with its production, cost, and capital investment guidance for 2026. The Company is also providing notice that it will release its fourth quarter and year-end 2025 financial results after market close on Tuesday, March 24, 2026. Andean will host its fourth quarter and year end 2025 earnings conference call and webcast on Wednesday, March 25, 2026, at 9:00 am Eastern Time.

Alberto Morales, Executive Chairman and CEO, stated, "Andean exited 2025 with a stronger fourth quarter production and improved momentum across the portfolio.

When viewed through a silver-equivalent lens, consolidated silver production in Q4 was approximately 1.4 million silver ounces, and 2025 consolidated silver production represents approximately 4.8 million silver ounces, highlighting the meaningful silver exposure within our portfolio. In parallel, we advanced exploration programs across our assets, supporting longer-term mine planning and enhancing our ability to unlock additional value from our existing operations.

Looking ahead to 2026, we anticipate a well-balanced production profile, with approximately 45% in the first half and 55% in the second half, reflecting the mining sequence at Golden Queen and the ore delivery schedule at San Bartolome. Our capital investment program for the year is aligned with our value creation strategy and supports processing improvements and operational flexibility.

With disciplined capital allocation, a competitive cost structure, and exposure to both gold and silver prices, the Company is well positioned to generate strong margins, free cash flow, and long-term value for our shareholders."

Q4 and FY 2025 Highlights:

  • Fourth quarter 2025 consolidated production of 27,777 gold equivalent ounces3 and full year 2025 consolidated production of 99,165 gold equivalent ounces3, near the bottom of the Company's full-year consolidated production guidance.

  • Golden Queen produced 11,828 gold equivalent ounces3 in the fourth quarter and 45,311 gold equivalent ounces3 for the full year 2025. Production in the fourth quarter benefited from an improved leach-cell permeability as identified earlier in the year and the implementation of optimized ore blending and leaching strategies.

  • San Bartolome produced 15,949 gold equivalent ounces3 in the fourth quarter and 53,854 gold equivalent ounces3 for the full year 2025 with continued emphasis on leveraging throughput capacity, optimizing recoveries, and securing long-term ore purchase agreements.

  • Record realized prices: In the fourth quarter the Company achieved an average realized gold price of $4,171/oz and average realized silver price of $59.88/oz, both higher than the spot market averages for gold and silver prices of $4,167/oz and $55.29/oz respectively

  • Golden Queen – expanded drilling program: The 2025 exploration program at Golden Queen was expanded following positive drilling results, including approximately 3,800 metres of core drilling added to the plan. Exploration activities during 2025 were focused on testing extensions of known mineralization with the objective of supporting potential mine life extension. An updated mineral resource estimate is expected to be released in mid-year 2026.

  • In June 2025, the Company entered into a long-term exclusive agreement with COMIBOL to acquire up to 7 million tonnes of oxide ore within 250 kilometres of the San Bartolome plant, enhancing feed security and supporting potential throughput growth. First ore deliveries are expected by the end of 2026.

Golden Queen Outlook

In 2025, exploration activities at Golden Queen made significant progress, marked by an expanded drilling program launched following encouraging results. The program remains focused on extending known mineralization and further refining mine planning, setting the stage for the 2026 exploration program, which is now underway with the objective of extending mine life.

Building on these developments, the Company has commenced work to expand the existing leach pad by adding capacity for an additional 3 million tonnes of ore. In addition, detailed engineering and permitting for a new leach pad are undergoing final review. Together, these initiatives are expected to extend leaching capacity through 2033.

To support anticipated production requirements, the mobile fleet will be increased by three additional haul trucks, bringing the total fleet size to twelve during 2026. Golden Queen also replaced the stacker and the agglomeration drum, improvements that enhanced ore stacking quality. The agglomeration process improved the quality of the stacked material, while the new stacker enhanced blending and reduced fine particle segregation. These improvements are expected to result in higher solution percolation rates and reduced particle migration. The Merrill-Crowe Plant is undergoing an upgrade from a capacity of approximately 3,000 gallons per minute (GPM) to 4,000 GPM, with commissioning planned for the fourth quarter. This upgrade is expected to increase gold and silver production from the leach pad by approximately 6 to 10% by directing a higher proportion of lower-grade solution to the Merrill-Crowe process and reducing the volume sent to the operating pond.

San Bartolome Outlook

In 2025, San Bartolome advanced its ore supply strategy by establishing new ore purchase agreements with local communities, supporting long-term operational stability while broadening its network of business partners. In addition, the Company finalized a long-term agreement with COMIBOL to acquire up to 7 million tonnes of oxide ore within a 250-kilometre radius of the processing facility. The first delivery of ore is anticipated by the end of 2026, increasing the diversity of feed sources over the long term and enhancing future feed strategies.

Transportation logistics at San Bartolome were notably improved in 2025, contributing to a 21% increase in processing throughput compared to the previous year. Building on this progress, the focus in 2026 will be on improving processing recoveries through automation initiatives and the construction of an additional thickener, scheduled for completion in the first quarter of 2027. These process improvements are expected to improve recovery rates by approximately 0.5% to 1.0%.

2026 Guidance

At Golden Queen, capital investment in 2026 is primarily directed toward infrastructure and mine development initiatives supporting exploration results and potential mine life extension. Planned expenditures include the expansion of the existing leach pad, detailed engineering and permitting for the construction of a new leach pad, acquisition of three additional haul trucks, deferred waste stripping, and upgrades to the Merrill-Crowe facility. These investments are intended to ensure sufficient processing capacity and operational flexibility to support anticipated future production requirements.

At San Bartolome, capital spending in 2026 is focused on processing enhancements and sustaining infrastructure. Planned capital expenditures include the construction of an additional thickener and related plant optimization initiatives designed to improve overall plant performance.

Q4 2025 Conference Call and Webcast

  • Wednesday, March 25, at 9:00 AM ET

  • Participants may listen to the webcast by registering via the following link https://www.gowebcasting.com/14609

  • Participants may also listen to the conference call by calling North American toll free 1-800-715-9871, or 1-647-932-3411 outside the U.S. or Canada.

  • An archived replay of the webcast will be available for 90 days at: https://www.gowebcasting.com/14609 or the Company website at www.andeanpm.com.

About Andean Precious Metals

Andean is a growing precious metals producer focused on expanding into top-tier jurisdictions in the Americas. The Company owns and operates the San Bartolome processing facility in Potosí, Bolivia and the Golden Queen mine in Kern County, California, and is well-funded to act on future growth opportunities. Andean's leadership team is committed to creating value; fostering safe, sustainable and responsible operations; and achieving our ambition to be a multi-asset, mid-tier precious metals producer.

Qualified Person Statement

The scientific and technical content disclosed in this news release was reviewed and approved by Yohann Bouchard, President of the Company. Mr. Bouchard has over 30 years of mining experience in progressively senior leadership positions, is a professional engineer with Professional Engineers Ontario, holds a Bachelor of Mining Engineering degree from Ecole Polytechnique of Montreal, and is a Qualified Person as defined by National Instrument 43-101 – Standards of Disclosure for Mineral Projects of the Canadian Securities Administrators.

For more information, please contact:

Amanda Mallough

Director, Investor Relations

amallough@andeanpm.com

T: +1 647 463 7808

Endnotes

  • "Cash cost", "all-in-sustaining costs" (or "AISC"), "cash gross operating margins" (or "CGOM"), "gross margin ratio" (or "GMR"), "sustaining capital", and "growth capital" are all non-GAAP financial performance measures that are used in this news release. These measures do not have any standardized meaning under IFRS and therefore may not be compatible to similar measures presented by other issuers. For more information about these measures and why they are used by the Company, see the "Non-GAAP Financial Measures, Ratios, and Supplementary Financial Measures" section (the "MD&A Information") of the Company's Management's Discussion & Analysis for the three and nine months ended September 30, 2025, available under the Company's profile on SEDAR+ at www.sedarplus.ca. The MD&A Information is incorporated by reference into this press release.

  • Golden Queen produces silver as a by-product of its gold production. The calculation of Cash Cost and AISC per gold ounce is net of by-product silver sales revenue.

  • Gold equivalent ounces of silver produced or sold in a given period are computed using a consistent ratio of the silver price to the gold price. In 2025, the Company is using a factor of 90. For 2026, the Company is using a factor of 85.

  • The Company has assumed a foreign exchange rate of $9.00 Bolivian Bolivianos to $1.00 U.S. dollar in its guidance.

data.title: Alcoa Corporation Declares Quarterly Cash Dividend
data.description:
PITTSBURGH--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 26, 2026--

Alcoa Corporation (; ) today announced that its Board of Directors has declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.10 per share of the Company's common stock, to be paid on March 26, 2026 to stockholders of record as of the close of business on March 10, 2026.

About Alcoa Corporation

Alcoa is a global industry leader in bauxite, alumina and aluminum products with a vision to build a legacy of excellence for future generations. With a values-based approach that encompasses integrity, operating excellence, care for people, and courageous leadership, our purpose is to Turn Raw Potential into Real Progress. Since developing the process that made aluminum an affordable and vital part of modern life, our talented Alcoans have developed breakthrough innovations and best practices that have led to greater efficiency, safety, sustainability, and stronger communities wherever we operate.

Dissemination of Company Information

Alcoa intends to make future announcements regarding company developments and financial performance through its website, www.alcoa.com, as well as through press releases, filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, conference calls, media broadcasts, and webcasts. Alcoa does not incorporate the information contained on, or accessible through, its corporate website into this press release.
